titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Louise Glück Papers
titlestmt.author: by Beinecke staff

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Tuesday April 23, 2019 at 04:22

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Louise Glück Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Collections are processed to a variety of levels, depending on the work necessary to make them usable, their perceived research value, the availability of staff, competing priorities, and whether or not further accruals are expected. The library attempts to provide a basic level of preservation and access for all collections as they are acquired, and does more extensive processing of higher priority collections as time and resources permit.
This collection received a basic level of processing, including rehousing and minimal organization.

Information included in the Description of Papers note and Collection Contents section is drawn from information supplied with the collection and from an initial survey of the contents. Folder titles appearing in the contents list below are often based on those provided by the creator or previous custodian. Titles have not been verified against the contents of the folders in all cases. Otherwise, folder titles are supplied by staff during initial processing.
This finding aid may be updated periodically to account for new acquisitions to the collection and/or revisions in arrangement and description.

acqinfo.head: Immediate Source of Acquisition
acqinfo.p: Purchased from Wylie Agency on the Edwin J. Beinecke Book Fund, 2008.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Louise Glück Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.
Box 39: Restricted until 2050. For further information consult the appropriate curator.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into six series: I. Correspondence, 1950s-2005. II. Writings, 1950s-2006. III. Writings of Others, 1970s-2005. IV. Other Papers, 1950s-1990s. V. Artwork, 1958-1965. VI. Restricted Material.

bioghist.head: Louise Glück
bioghist.p: Louise Glück is an American poet. She was awarded the Pulitzer Prize for Poetry in 1993 for The Wild Iris, and the Bollingen Prize for Poetry in 2001. Glück served as the Poet Laureate Consultant in Poetry to the Library of Congress, 2003-2004.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The collection consists of correspondence, writings, notebooks, writings of others, ephemera, photographs, and artwork documenting the life adn work of poet Louise Glück. Correspondence spans Glück's career and includes poets Steven Berg, Robert Pinsky, C. K. Williams, and others, as well as family correspondence. Writings include individual poems and drafts of collections including Ararat, The Wild Iris, Meadowlands, and Vita Nova. Writings of others include works by numerous writers including Steven Berg, Frank Bidart, Kathryn Davis, Robert Pinsky, Ellen Bryant Voigt, and C. K.Williams. Artwork includes oil paintings and watercolors by Louise Glück.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains "Desire," "For Bill Nestrick (1941-96)," "For the Twentieth Century," "Heart Beat," "Legacy," "Luggage," "Music Like Dirt," "The Poem is a Viel," "The Second Hour of the Night," "Star Dust," and other poems. Also contains correspondence and interviews.
